track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Fire Safety
track.annotation: A Christmas Eve house fire killed an Oklahoma City woman. Family members say that 82-year old Allene Barr was disabled and could not escape her burning home.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Dram Law Crackdown
track.annotation: The ABLE Commission and law enforcement are teaming-up to get drunk drivers off the road this New Year’s Eve. The plan is to crackdown on anyone who serves and sells alcohol to customers who are already intoxicated.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: CPA Survey and David Greenwell Interview
track.annotation: Despite reports of revenue shortfalls and the possibility of more cuts to state agencies, Oklahoma CPA’s are sounding upbeat about the state’s economy. CPA David Greenwell joined us to talk about it.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Animal Park
track.annotation: The tough economy is taking a toll on animal sanctuaries. An animal park in Wynnewood is hoping animal lovers will help them continue to provide a home for a variety of animals who are in need.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Norman Water Study
track.annotation: The city of Norman has elevated levels of a cancer-causing chemical in its drinking water. But officials at the Department of Environmental Quality say Norman's water is still safe to drink.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Foreclosure Filings and Doyle Province Interview
track.annotation: More Oklahomans are facing foreclosure on their homes. More than 58-hundred foreclosure filings were reported in the third quarter of 2010. That’s a two-percent increase over the previous quarter.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Wal-Mart Food Bank Challenge
track.annotation: Wal-Mart wants to give one American community one million dollars to fight hunger. The retail giant has launched a social media contest, and food banks in Oklahoma City and Tulsa are competing for the prize.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Education Legal Battles
track.annotation: Sandy Garrett chaired her last meeting of the State Board of Education. Some of the topics discussed at the meeting were health insurance and legal battles surrounding the Teachers Retirement Fund.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Beggs School Closed
track.annotation: More than twelve-hundred students in Beggs, Oklahoma are getting an extended winter holiday. School officials cancelled classes a little early for the Christmas break, after a student was diagnosed with viral meningitis.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Teen Drug Use
track.annotation: A new report from the National Institute of Drug Abuse indicates that tobacco smoking among teenagers is down, but marijuana and prescription drug use is rising.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Animal Shelters
track.annotation: Animal shelters across the state are offering special adoption programs to coincide with the holiday season. For those animals who will spend the next several weeks in a wire cage with a cement floor, there is something people can do to make that time more comfortable and less stressful.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Ersland Ruling
track.annotation: Judge Ray Elliott has refused to step down as the presiding judge in the murder trial of Jerome Ersland, the Oklahoma City pharmacist accused of killing a teenager during an armed robbery. Defense lawyers for Ersland wanted Elliott to withdraw from the case, alleging he made racist comments.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: No Aliens Live Interview
track.annotation: Four years ago, Sylvia Browne, a physic, made the prediction that aliens were going to visit earth this year. Oklahoma City University professor Bryan Farha, operates the Internet blog site, “Smoke and Mirrors.” Farha is closing in on debunking the prediction, and he joined us live to talk about it.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Fake Cops
track.annotation: The tiny Creek County town of Shamrock is the target of multiple investigations. Allegations include possible misuse of public money, improperly attempting to dissolve a town government, and illegally selling or granting police commissions.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: All About Christmas
track.annotation: The spirit of the holidays is alive and well in Oklahoma. A number of events are planned in order to ensure that some of the state’s neediest children have presents under the tree.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Shady Point Revealed
track.annotation: The owners of a coal-fired power plan in southeastern Oklahoma have gone on the offensive against claims that a by-product of the plant is making people sick.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Ersland Day 2
track.annotation: A high profile criminal case continues to attract attention. Defense attorneys for Jerome Ersland want his trial to be moved from Oklahoma City. Ersland, a pharmacist, is accused of murdering a teenager during an armed robbery attempt.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Energy Sector
track.annotation: Oklahoma’s oil and gas industry continues to rebound from the recession. Nineteen new rigs have been added in the past two weeks, bringing the state’s total to 151. We talk about the industry’s economic impact on our state with Steve Agee, Interim Dean of the Meinders School of Business at Oklahoma City University.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Ersland Judge
track.annotation: Attorneys for a pharmacist accused of murder wants the judge in the case to be removed. The hearing took place at the Oklahoma County Courthouse.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Care for Troops
track.annotation: ‘Tis the season for giving, and that is one of the reasons why “care packages” are making their way to Afghanistan to brighten the holidays for military personnel who can’t be with their families this Christmas.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Ponca City Children's Home Live Interview
track.annotation: Forty-four children at the American Legion Children's Home in Ponca City face an uncertain Christmas.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Dester Center
track.annotation: A new emergency shelter for children entering foster care has been dedicated in Tulsa. The facility, and its operation, is a public-private partnership committed to improving the lives of children.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: World AIDS Day
track.annotation: World AIDS Day took place this week, and state health officials used the occasion to reflect on the collective struggles against the AIDS virus. Here in Oklahoma, the number of AIDS cases increases each year.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Meth Law
track.annotation: Oklahomans who have been convicted of methamphetamine-related offenses can no longer buy cold medicines containing pseudoephedrine. Darrell Weaver, Director of the Oklahoma Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, joined us to discuss the impact of this new law.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Smoking Ban
track.annotation: The Oklahoma Municipal League wants towns and cities across the state to have the power to ban smoking in public places.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Children's Home
track.annotation: The American Legion Board of Directors has voted to close its Children's Home in Ponca City. The future of 44 children and their caretakers remains uncertain.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sharia Law Update and Live Interview
track.annotation: Citing the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, Oklahoma City Federal Judge, Vicki Miles Legrange, has ordered a preliminary injunction against State Question 755. In our newsmaker interview, Muneer Awad, Executive Director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, talks about what he sees as the negative impact of this voter-approved state questions.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: 219th Returns
track.annotation: Thirty-one military men and women made it home from Iraq and Afghanistan in time for Thanksgiving. ONR was there as members of the 219th Engineering Installation Squadron landed in Oklahoma City.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sex Offenders
track.annotation: The city of Sand Springs is taking unusual steps to keep sex offenders away from residents.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Pros for Vets
track.annotation: A diverse group of individuals and organizations have joined forces to raise awareness about issues facing Oklahoma veterans.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: ONR Extra Forum 755
track.annotation: On this week's Oklahoma Forum program, legal scholars from the University of Oklahoma and Oklahoma City law schools discussed the impact and constitutionality of State Question 755.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: SQ 755
track.annotation: A federal judge continues to block an amendment to the state Constitution that bans Sharia or International Law from being considered in Oklahoma courts.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Execution Drugs
track.annotation: A hearing was held in Oklahoma City Federal Court to determine if the Corrections Department can substitute one of the drugs used in the three-drug mixture to carry out executions in Oklahoma.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: ONR Extra Women in Prison
track.annotation: Oklahoma continues to lead the nation in the number of women it puts behind bars. The Oklahoma Bar Association examined the reasons why during their yearly convention.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Eye Witnesses
track.annotation: Oklahoma has had its share of wrongful convictions. Some of those cases involved eye witness testimony that turned out to be inaccurate. The state Bar Association examined the issue at its annual convention.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: TRS and Meacham
track.annotation: Outgoing State Treasurer, Scott Meacham, has a six-point plan to infuse the state's financially troubled public employees pension system. During a live interview on the ONR, Meacham explained the plan, and answered questions about where it will likely face opposition.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Bar Association Meeting
track.annotation: Attorneys from across the state gathered to discuss a variety of legal issues, including eye witness testimony that leads to false accusations and convictions, and Oklahoma's high number of women in prison.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Bokoshe Flyash
track.annotation: A group of residents from the northeastern Oklahoma town of Bokoshe are concerned about flyash near their town. Flyash is a by-product of coal mining, and many residents believe it is making them sick. The Corporation Commission held a hearing to discuss the regulation of coal waste disposal, and several of the residents turned up to voice their concerns.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Oklahoma Hunger
track.annotation: Oklahoma ranks fifth in the nation for food insecurity. The number of Oklahomans going hungry or underfed continues to increase.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Creativity Day 1
track.annotation: The opening session of the World Forum on Creativity in Oklahoma City, featured Blake Mycoskie, founder of "Tom's Shoes." His company provides thousands of free shoes to people in need all over the world.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: TSA Patdowns
track.annotation: New TSA security protocols are in place at major airports, including Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City. The new measures include full body scans and pat-downs.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Creativity Project
track.annotation: People from across the nation and around the globe are in Oklahoma this week for a discussion on Creativity. The World Creativity Forum is designed to share information about "creative" ways of problem-solving in all fields of endeavor.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Human Trafficking
track.annotation: Oklahoma law enforcement officers are being trained to spot instances of human trafficking. The Sooner state is seen as a "pass-through" state, which means Oklahoma's interstate highways are used regularly by human traffickers.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Pecan Harvest
track.annotation: Oklahoma’s pecan harvest is underway. Even though the pecan industry still suffers from the effects of the ice storm of 2007, this year's crop is better than expected.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Women and Careers
track.annotation: With the right education, even in these tough economic times, job possibilities are available for women. The OSU Institute of Technology in Okmulgee is recruiting women to enroll in course work that will help them find good jobs.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: End of White Pages
track.annotation: Telephone listings in the "white pages" may soon be a thing of the past in Oklahoma. The issue is finding new support among some state legislators.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Homeless Veterans
track.annotation: As people from all across the state observed Veterans Day, the effort to reduce the growing number of homeless vets in Oklahoma continues.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Higher Education Regents
track.annotation: Regents for Higher Education will ask the Oklahoma legislature for a 5.56% increase in funding for the next fiscal year, despite the ongoing shortfall in state government funding.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Small Business Conference
track.annotation: Hundreds of small high tech developers from across the state gathered at a national conference held in Oklahoma City. Representatives from numerous federal agencies told the attendees about federal money that is available for technology innovation and research in Oklahoma.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Senate President
track.annotation: The Republican majority in the state Senate has tapped Sapulpa State Senator, Brian Bingman, as the new President Pro-Tem.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Bokoshe Flyash Contamination
track.annotation: Residents in the small Oklahoma town of Bokoshe say an industrial by-product of mining, called "flyash," is killing them. Environmentalists agree, but the owners of the mine say no one is at risk. KOTV reporter Jennifer Loren investigated, and she shares her in-depth report with us.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: CAIR Threats
track.annotation: The leader of a Muslim advocacy group in Oklahoma City is receiving hate mail and threats in the wake of a lawsuit that has been filed against the passage of State Question 755. That question was approved by voters in the November election. It prohibits the use of Sharia or international law in Oklahoma courts.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sharia Court Challenge
track.annotation: A federal judge has blocked a constitutional amendment concerning Sharia Law, at least for now. Oklahoma voters just recently approved a State Question, which would forbid courts in our state from considering Sharia or International Law.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Safe Kids
track.annotation: The annual summit on "Safe Schools" focused on the issue of bullying.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: SQ 751 Challenge
track.annotation: A University of Tulsa professor plans to challenge two state questions in court. Jim Thomas believes State Questions 751 and 746 are unconstitutional. The two questions were just approved by voters on Nov 2nd. One question makes English the state's official language, and the other question requires voters to show proof of identity before voting.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Quality Jobs
track.annotation: A company in Broken Arrow that makes custom oil field equipment is getting ready for massive expansion. The company needs hundreds of new workers, from welders and electricians, to engineers and office staff. "Ener-flow" is using the Quality Jobs Program to fuel their expansion.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: CAIR Lawsuit Live Interview
track.annotation: Peter F. Krug is a Professor of Law at the University of Oklahoma. He teaches courses in Human Rights Law, Comparative Law, and International Law. He was interviewed by OETA's Dick Pryor about the passage of State Question 755, which prohibits Oklahoma courts from using Sharia or international law.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: CAIR Lawsuit
track.annotation: A lawsuit has been filed against a controversial ballot measure that bans Oklahoma courts from considering Sharia or international law. A Muslim advocacy group believes that State Question 755, which was passed overwhelmingly by voters, is unconstitutional, because it unfairly singles out the Islamic faith.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Prison Graduation
track.annotation: It was graduation day for eight women from the “Women in Recovery” program in Tulsa. The program is designed to divert non-violent female offenders from prison into a program that helps them rebuild their lives.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Bullying
track.annotation: The story of one family’s loss because their son was the victim of bullying in school and how state government is now looking for new solutions to the age old problem.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: New Law Uninsured Vehicles
track.annotation: A new law, designed to get uninsured vehicles off Oklahoma roadways, goes into effect November 1st. If a law enforcement officer determines that a vehicle is not insured, that vehicle will be impounded on the spot.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Pensions and Live Interview
track.annotation: The stage is set for a battle in the upcoming legislative session over changes to the state employee pension funds. Two groups are squared-off already, and politics is expected to be added to the mix.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Higher Education and Live Interview
track.annotation: Chancellor of Higher Education, Glenn Johnson, talks about a host of issues now facing colleges and universities in Oklahoma. Even with enrollment at record levels, the cost of going to college in our state keeps going up.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Water Conference
track.annotation: At the start of the Governor's annual Water Conference, the Oklahoma Secretary of the Environment issued a report on the state's water supply.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Meth Cleanup Law
track.annotation: The city of Tulsa may join three other communities and create an ordinance intended to cleanup meth labs. The ordinance would require property owners to certify that their property has been cleaned of all chemicals before that property can be sold or rented. Supporters believe the ordinance will help fight the environmental hazards caused by meth lab contamination.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Anti-Poverty Campaign
track.annotation: Tulsa is one of eight cities across the nation implementing a new program designed to battle poverty. While the poverty rate in Oklahoma City stands at 13%, the rate in Tulsa has jumped to 20%. Mayor Dewey Bartlett is among those leading the fight to lower his city's rate of unemployment, poverty, and hunger.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Stuff the Bus
track.annotation: As thousands of Oklahoma National Guardsmen prepare to deploy to Afghanistan, several non-profit groups have joined forces to help military families get through the holidays. Dubbed, "Stuff the Bus," donations filled the bus with winter clothes, toys, books, and food, for nearly 150 military families.
